snippet: Iraqi airspace has emerged as a main supply route for weapons from Iran, which has an enormous stake in Syria, at a time when President Bashar al-Assad is under increasing pressure from rebel fighters.
abstract: American effort to stem flow of Iranian arms to Syria has faltered because of Iraq's reluctance to inspect aircraft carrying weapons through its airspace; air corridor over Iraq has emerged as main supply route for weapons; Western officials are also concerned about new signs of activity at sites in Syria that are used to store chemical weapons.

byline.original: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, ERIC SCHMITT and TIM ARANGO
byline.contributor: Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt reported from Washington, and Tim Arango from Baghdad. David E. Sanger contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Iraqi airspace has emerged as a main supply route for weapons from Iran, which has an enormous stake in Syria, at a time when President Bashar al-Assad is under increasing pressure from rebel fighters.

headline.main: Flow of Arms to Syria Through Iraq Persists, to U.S. Dismay
headline.print_headline: U.S. Is Stumbling In Keeping Arms From Damascus
